prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Galaxy 1: dense gas
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation of HCN (1--0) and HCO+ (1--0) for post-starburst galaxy "S02".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We estimate the required sensitivity for the HCN observations using data taken with the IRAM 30m. This galaxy has a peak flux of 40mJy, and a FWHM of 200 km/s in CO (1--0). Poststarbursts are expected to have a low HCN to CO ratio, and Kohno et al. (2002) find the brightness temperature ratio to be 2%. We then estimate the peak flux of this galaxy in HCN to be 2% of 40 mJy, or 0.8mJy. We would like a signal to noise of 5, in order to detect the dense gas at this level. This is a meaningful limit, as a 2% ratio is below what is expected for normal galaxies. Gao and Solomon (2004) predict a L'(HCN)/L'(CO) value of 3.9%. If we detect no HCN emission for this galaxy, we will know it lies significantly below the dense gas- star formation rate relation seen for normal galaxies.
Our emphasis for this science goal is total luminosity. As such, we plan to bin the data over the entire bandwidth of the line to increase sensitivity.
Similarly, we do not require high angular resolution for these data. We would like to observe in the most compact configuration. We have an estimate on the angular size of the CO emitting region from CO (2--1) data taken with both the IRAM 30m and SMT 10m, of 33 arcsec, though, we expect the dense gas to be more compact. We expect that the dense gas will have a spatial extent similar to the A star distribution in the galaxy. These are stars that were created in the recent starburst, and which dominate the optical light. The half-light radius in the r band is 5 arcsec as measured by the SDSS, so we do not expect the flux per beam to be diluted beyond the 4.3 arcsec resolution elements of these observations.
We expect the HCO+ line to be of similar total flux as the HCN, so we plan to take advantage of the proximity of these lines, and observe both.
We have no time constraints, or other special requests.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Galaxy 2: dense gas
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation of HCN (1--0) and HCO+ (1--0) for post-starburst galaxy "H03".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We estimate the required sensitivity for the HCN observations using data taken with the IRAM 30m. This galaxy has a peak flux of 90mJy, and a FWHM of 200 km/s in CO (1--0). Poststarbursts are expected to have a low HCN to CO ratio, and Kohno et al. (2002) find the brightness temperature ratio to be 2%. We then estimate the peak flux of this galaxy in HCN to be 2% of 40 mJy, or 1.8mJy. We would like a signal to noise of 3, in order to detect the dense gas at this level. This is a meaningful limit, as a 2% ratio is below what is expected for normal galaxies. Gao and Solomon (2004) predict a L'(HCN)/L'(CO) value of 3.9%. If we detect no HCN emission for this galaxy, we will know it lies significantly below the dense gas- star formation rate relation seen for normal galaxies.
Our emphasis for this science goal is total luminosity. As such, we intend to bin over the entire bandwidth of the line to increase sensitivity.
Similarly, we do not require high angular resolution for these data. We would like to observe in the most compact configuration. We have an upper limit on the angular size of the CO emitting region from CO (2--1) data taken with both the IRAM 30m and SMT 10m, of 7 arcsec. Although we expect the dense gas to be more compact than this, it is important that we measure the dense gas emission from this entire region. We expect that the dense gas will have a spatial extent similar to the A star distribution in the galaxy. These are stars that were created in the recent starburst, and which dominate the optical light. The half-light radius in the r band is 7 arcsec as measured by the SDSS. Using 4.3 arcsec resolution, the worst case scenario for sensitivity is the flux per beam divided into four resolution elements. We divide the sensitivity estimate by four to arrive at our requested sensitivity of 0.15mJy.
We expect the HCO+ line to be of similar total flux as the HCN, so we plan to take advantage of the proximity of these lines, and observe both.
We have no time constraints, or other special requests.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Galaxy 1: CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of CO (1--0) for the post-starburst galaxy S02.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We estimate the required sensitivity for the CO observations using data taken with the IRAM 30m. This galaxy has a peak flux of 40mJy, and a FWHM of 200 km/s in CO (1--0). We would like to observe a CO map of this galaxy with signal to noise of at least 3. Our spatial resolution goals are driven by our desire to understand the observed offset from the Kennicutt-Schmidt relation. We would like to resolve the distribution of CO, and compare it to the A star distribution (5 arcsec for this galaxy). This sets our desired resolution at 2.5 arcsec in order to adequately compare the two. We have an estimate on the angular size of the CO emitting region from CO (2--1) data taken with both the IRAM 30m and SMT 10m, of 33 arcsec, which sets our maximum size. This size is larger than the maximum recoverable scale for this frequency for the 12m array, so we request the ACA.
The post-starburst sample could be reconciled with the K-S relation if the gas was 2.5 times more extended than the A star distribution. In order to estimate the sensitivity required, we set the worst case scenario as one where the gas is evenly distributed across this size, or 12.5 arcsec for this galaxy. Using a resolution of 2.5 arcsec, we divide the expected flux into 25 resolution elements. We then require a sensitivity of 0.53mJy.
Our emphasis for this science goal is the overall CO distribution. As such, we plan to bin the data over the entire bandwidth of the line to increase sensitivity.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Galaxy 2: CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of CO (1--0) for post-starburst galaxy "H03".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We estimate the required sensitivity for the CO observations using data taken with the IRAM 30m. This galaxy has a peak flux of 90mJy, and a FWHM of 200 km/s in CO (1--0). We would like to observe a CO map of this galaxy with signal to noise of at least 3. Our spatial resolution goals are driven by our desire to understand the observed offset from the Kennicutt-Schmidt relation. We would like to resolve the distribution of CO, and compare it to the A star distribution (5 arcsec for this galaxy), as well as the size the star formation region would need to be to resolve the discrepancy with the K-S relation (2 arcsec). We have an upper limit on the angular size of the CO emitting region from CO (2--1) data taken with both the IRAM 30m and SMT 10m, of 7 arcsec, which sets our maximum size.
In the IRAM 30m spectra, a double peak feature is seen for this galaxy. We would like to resolve the kinematics of this feature, so we require a spectral resolution of 50 km/s.
We take advantage of the brightness of this line to get excellent spatial resolution for the sensitivity required. We request 1 arcsec resolution. Conservatively, if the flux from the line as observed by the single dish is evenly divided across the field, we divide the flux into 49 resolution elements. Thus, we require a sensitivity of 0.61mJy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We have identified a unique sample of post-starburst, post-merger galaxies, in transition between late-type and early-type galaxies based on their tidal features, bulge-dominated morphologies, evolving color gradients, and young globular cluster populations (Yang et al. 2004, 2006, 2008). Remarkably, we have discovered molecular gas with the IRAM 30m in 17 of the 32 post-starburst galaxies studied, and found them to lie off the classical Kennicutt-Schmidt relation in the sense that they have higher molecular gas surface densities than predicted by their star-formation rates. We have narrowed down possible explanations for this offset to two questions that can only be answered with ALMA. The first is whether or not the molecular gas has a similar or more extended distribution than the optical light. By spatially resolving the CO emission, we can accurately measure the molecular gas surface densities. The second is whether or not CO is the best tracer of the current star-forming regions. We propose to observe the HCN and HCO+ emission from these galaxies to study the dense gas fraction.
